translated: The Book of Conditional Relations🔽The Chapter on the Triad

original: Dhammānulomapaccanīya (3), Dukatikapaṭṭhānapāḷi (3)🔽15.86. Saraṇaduka, Uppannattika🔽Saraṇo anuppanno dhammo nasaraṇassa naanuppannassa dhammassa ārammaṇapaccayena paccayo. Ārammaṇe cattāri, adhipatiyā tīṇi, upanissaye cattāri.🔽Araṇo uppādī dhammo naaraṇassa nauppādissa dhammassa ārammaṇapaccayena paccayo. Araṇo🔽uppādī dhammo nasaraṇassa nauppādissa dhammassa ārammaṇapaccayena paccayo. Ārammaṇe
analyzed: dhamma anuloma paccanīya  saraṇa duka  saraṇaḥ anuppannaḥ dhammaḥ na saraṇassa na anuppannassa dhammassa ārammaṇa paccayena paccayaḥ ārammaṇe cattāri adhipatiyā tīṇi upanissaye cattāri  araṇaḥ uppādī dhammaḥ na araṇassa na uppādissa dhammassa ārammaṇa paccayena paccayaḥ araṇaḥ  uppādī dhammaḥ na saraṇassa na auppādissa dhammassa ārammaṇa paccayena paccayaḥ ārammaṇe
translated: The Triad on the Unconditioned🔽An unarisen unconditioned element is a condition, as object condition, for an unarisen unconditioned element. In the triad, there are four in object condition, three in predominance condition, and four in support condition.

An arisen unconditioned element is a condition, as object condition, for an unarisen unconditioned element. An arisen unconditioned element is a condition, as object condition, for an unarisen unconditioned element. In the triad, there are two in object condition, one in predominance condition, and two in support condition.
